He went into the city to share his guard.
They didn't get a single thing.
Next, he went to the gate of a great and powerful man.
He had obtained crude and unwholesome food.
He was about to leave the city.

source_sentence: 門中逢一射獵殺生屠兒。
translation: In the gate, he met a butcher's son who was hunting and killing people.
He was holding a dog in his arms and wanted to kill it.
When he saw the ascetic, he rejoiced and paid homage to him.
The monk incanted, "May I live a long life!

source_sentence: 沙門知有狗子欲殺噉之。
translation: The monk knew there was a dog that he wanted to kill and devour.
He asked what he wanted to do with it.
He replied.
"It's empty and active.
The monk then asked.
"I've seen the sin of killing life.
It's very bad.
May you take my food and trade it for this dog's son.
That will give him life and help him achieve immeasurable merit.
The man didn't give it to me.

source_sentence: 沙門慇懃曉喻請之不肯隨言。
translation: The monk invited him with an earnest request, refusing to comply.
The monk then said.
"Suppose he won't accept it.
'You can show me.'
The man then produced it.
He showed it to the monk.
The monk raised a dish of rice to placate the dog.
He put his hand on it, incanting a wish and releasing tears.
'Your sin caused you to get the body of this dog.
You can't freely see, kill, and eat it.
It will cause the cessation of sins and the production of merit in all the generations to come.
Secluded from the body of a dog, you'll be born a human being.
Where he is, he encounters the Dharma.
When the dog cub gets to eat, good thoughts arise.
He rises up and rejoices, and then he leaves after the deed.
He returns home and kills the food.
The dog's life is over.
He'll be born to a wealthy, powerful elder.
He'll be born and fall to the ground.
He then had a compassionate mind.
It was then that that ascetic.
He went to the elder's door in turn as a guard.
The elder's son then saw that ascetic.
He remembered the original object of his consciousness.
He bowed his head at the ascetic's feet and saluted him.
He asked him to make offerings of a hundred flavors of food and drink.
He then said to his parents.
"Now, I want to banish this great monk.
I want to receive the precepts from the scriptures and become a disciple.
My parents loved him and wouldn't listen to him.
Now, there's one of your sons in my school.
I will continue after him.

source_sentence: 家門之主何因便欲棄我而去。
translation: Why would the head of the family want to abandon me?
The little boy wailed and refused to eat.
He doesn't want to listen to me, so he takes his own life.
Seeing this, his parents then allowed him to leave.
He followed his teacher and trained on the path.
He took off his hair and moustache and put on the three Dharma robes.
He recited the Buddha's sūtras.
He deeply understood their meaning.
He then attained samādhi.
He establishes irreversibility.
He reveals and transforms all [sentient beings].
He gives rise to the great intention of the great way.
That's when the ascetic realizes past lives.
He gives rise to the bodhisattva aspiration.
He establishes irreversibility.
How could it be possible for someone to do that?
He makes offerings to the Three Treasures.

source_sentence: 諷誦大乘(出度脫狗子經)。
translation: He recites the great vehicle (out of the Sutra of Liberation of the Dogs).
Sutra, Vinaya, and Different Aspects, Vol. 12
